profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was encoding in EAD by Archon 2.22 from an SQL database source on May 19th, 2010.

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: The papers of New York City banker and businessman Samuel Flewwelling (1774 or 5-1849) primarily relating to property held by his wife, Julia Elvira Canfield Flewwelling (1791-1868), and him in the Western Reserve, later Ohio. Following Samuel's death, the properties were managed by William Mackay (1795-1873), a New York City businessman and the husband of Caroline Emma Canfield Mackay. The collections includes indentures, agreements, leases, deeds, statements and accounts, and correspondence.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Samuel Flewwelling was born in 1774 or 1775, a son of Abel Flewwelling and Abigail Fowler Flewwelling of Newburgh, N.Y. The Flewwellings moved to New Brunswick during or shortly after the American Revolution. Samuel became associated with William Rhinelander in New York in 1796 and joined the Manhattan Bank in 1801 as bookkeeper. He was promoted to more responsible positions, becoming cashier of the Poughkeepsie branch in 1809. In 1810, he returned to the main office to become cashier until 1817, when he became cashier of the City Bank. He was the cashier of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company from 1825 until 1829, when he became cashier of the National Bank in New York. Flewwelling maintained residences in New York City and Nyack, N.Y. He retired in 1840 and died in 1849. Samuel Flewwelling married Julia Elvira Canfield, a daughter of Judson Canfield and Mabel Ruggles Canfield. Samuel and Julia Flewwelling had no children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of New York City banker and businessman Samuel Flewwelling (1774 or 5-1849) primarily relating to property held by his wife, Julia Elvira Canfield Flewwelling (1791-1868), and him in the Western Reserve, later Ohio. Following Samuel's death, the properties were managed by William Mackay (1795-1873), a New York City businessman and the husband of Caroline Emma Canfield Mackay. The collections includes indentures, agreements, leases, deeds, statements and accounts, and correspondence.

Samuel Flewwelling was born in 1774 or 1775, a son of Abel Flewwelling and Abigail Fowler Flewwelling of Newburgh, N.Y. The Flewwellings moved to New Brunswick during or shortly after the American Revolution. Samuel became associated with William Rhinelander in New York in 1796 and joined the Manhattan Bank in 1801 as bookkeeper. He was promoted to more responsible positions, becoming cashier of the Poughkeepsie branch in 1809. In 1810, he returned to the main office to become cashier until 1817, when he became cashier of the City Bank. He was the cashier of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company from 1825 until 1829, when he became cashier of the National Bank in New York. Flewwelling maintained residences in New York City and Nyack, N.Y. He retired in 1840 and died in 1849.

Samuel Flewwelling married Julia Elvira Canfield, a daughter of Judson Canfield and Mabel Ruggles Canfield. Samuel and Julia Flewwelling had no children. Julia's siblings were Henry J. Canfield (1789-1856) of Canfield, Ohio; Elizabeth Hannah Canfield Tallmadge (1793-1878); and Caroline Emma Canfield Mackay (1798-1872).

The papers are arranged chronologically in one series and consist mostly of documents concerning the conveyance land in the Western Reserve. The earliest document outlines the partitioning of land Judson Canfield and others purchased from the Connecticut Land Co. in 1799. Flewwelling acquired land from Canfield as early as 1815. Some of the later sales were among members of Flewwelling's family, including his father-in-law Judson Canfield, his brother-in-law Henry J. Canfield, and his brother- and sister-in-law Frederick Augustus Tallmadge and Elizabeth Canfield Tallmadge. Flewwelling provided mortgages to some of the purchasers of land, and the agreements contained in the papers spell out the payment terms.

For many years, Royal Millard served as Flewwelling's agent in Ohio, and the collection includes many of his letters reporting on the buying and selling of properties and the collection of funds. After Millard died in 1854, Henry Canfield and William H. Canfield, a nephew of Judson Canfield, served as agents in Ohio, and their letters are also represented in the collection.

Following Flewwelling's death in 1849, his brother-in-law William Mackay, a New York City businessman whose father William and brother Robert Mackay were wealthy Boston merchants, managed the Ohio lands for Julia Canfield Flewwelling. It appears that by the time of Mrs. Flewwelling's death in 1868 all of her and her late husband's Ohio land holdings may have been sold.
Of particular interest in the papers are several documents that summarize Flewwelling's property holdings and detail the contracts and deeds he held.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of Materials
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in one series:

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This Collection is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Flewwelling Papers (2010-96-0), Litchfield Historical Society, Helga J. Ingraham Memorial Library, P.O. Box 385, 7 South Street, Litchfield, Connecticut, 06759

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The materials were acquired by Litchfield Historical Society from Carroll Swope on 03/01/2010.

odd.head: Other Information
odd.p: This collection was processed with support from the Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR) and the National Historical Publications and Records Commission (NHPRC).

scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Detailed inventory of holdings and their values, including stocks, land, and other property. Total amount is $58,600.
Summary of activities, 1835-1847.

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Hall, Joseph; Hall, Sarah; and Flewwelling, Samuel

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.
Regarding two plats of land.
Encloses his account and a draft and acknowledges deeds received.
Received Flewwelling's receipt and is enclosing a draft.
Allen expresses his regrets regarding Flewwelling's death. He reports that he has a claim in Flewwelling's favor and will again contact Tallmadge to find out who the executors are.

did.unittitle: Tallmadge, Frederick S. to Mackay, William

scopecontent.p: Reports on advice provided by Mr. Noyes about notifying heirs and placing advertisements.
Acknowledges the news of Flewwelling's death and discusses business Flewwelling left to him.
Reports on property sold to Hilliard and Clark and asks for instructions on matters relating to Flewwelling's affairs and estate.
Encloses a letter received from D. Tooker listing the children of Charlotte Purdy, sister of Flewwelling.
Mr. Clark is eager to settle his affairs. He paid an inflated price for his land. Allen discusses what Allen may be willing to pay to settle and provides a recommended course of action.
Harding reports from St. John, Canada, on Flewwelling's relatives there.
Encloses a draft and reports that there are frequent applications to purchase Mackay's lands. Also, some purchasers of land have failed to pay.
Provides a copy of the power of attorney given Millard by Flewwelling. Reports on mortgages of Kidney, Barnum, and Cary.
Although he does not have authority, he has been collecting funds on Flewwelling's lands. Inquires about paying taxes due in December.

Discusses the Cary, Prosser Coon, and Barnum mortgages. Millard has paid taxes on all lands, including those of Mr. Tallmadge. A draft is enclosed. Discusses inquiries about purchasing lands and prices Henry Canfield has set.
Encloses a draft.
Proposes to sell to Henry Drier and William Drier the only 50 acres of land belonging to the estate of Flewwelling still unsold.

did.unittitle: Deed [wrapper], [Estate of Flewwelling, Samuel] to Coon, Prosser

scopecontent.p: Property in Section No. 9.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Flewwelling, Julia Canfield; Drier, Henry; and Drier, William

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.

Encloses a draft, the Drier and Drier contract, and his current account. He has the opportunity to make a small sale. Discusses Mason's loans and deeds. Believes that the law requires wills to be deposited in county where land lies.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Flewwelling, Julia Canfield and Barnum, George

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.
Discusses land sales relating to Brainard, Colbrenn, and Finney. Encloses two deeds belonging to Caroline Mackay.

Encloses a draft. He has been delayed due to ill health. Reports on taxes paid for Julia Canfield Flewwelling, William Mackay trust deeds, Caroline Canfield Mackay, and Henry Canfield. Reports on Henry Canfield's advice about selling land. Mackay's reply, dated Dec 20, 1850 is on the last page, in which he acknowledges Millard's letter and responds to Millard's proposals.

Encloses a draft. Reports on a German man, who has not purchased land as expected. There are no other opportunities to sell land and no inquiries. Offers his opinion about selling two 100-acre tracts held by Julia Canfield Flewwelling.
Discusses the claim due the estate of Flewwelling in which he is involved. Briefly mentions political climate in Washington, D.C.
Encloses a draft. His health is better. The German has not taken the contract and Millard will look for other purchasers.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Sexton, Albe; French, Collins; and Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Sexton, Albe; French, Collins; and Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.
Inquires about the chain of title to lot No. 79 in Cleveland, Ohio. Discusses the possibility of reducing his debt to as small an amount now due Mr. Hilliard.
Received W. D. Beall's deed. Millard's health is poor, but will comply with Mackay's requests as he can.
Encloses a statement of account and a draft. He has reviewed his accounts and had found no mistakes, believing the error to which Mackay referred is an omission concerning postage.
A detailed listing of notes and agreements in Millard's possession belonging to the estate of Samuel Flewwelling. Millard advises that his health is poor and there may be miscalculations.
He asks for a fair deduction on the balance due, and if so, he will discharge the debt in full.

did.unittitle: Canfield, Henry to Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: He is glad Julia's health is better. The notes she should send him are those of George Jones. Discusses Nelson Jones notes and hopes he can draw against those notes and what he is due from books sold from Mr. Mackay. Provides an accounting of funds received and used in the building his house.

Encloses a draft. Reports on a rail road laid leading from Cleveland to Toledo that passes through Mrs. Tallmadge's or Mackay's land in Rockford. Discusses the implications of the right of way and what the rail company will pay. Corrects a mistake he made in his previous account.
Discusses Henry Coons' contract and encourages settling with the rail road company soon.

Calvin Gidding is interested in purchasing part of Mrs. Flewwelling's property. Henry Canfield has requested Millard hold funds and the bargain with Beall is not closed for some unknown reason to Millard.
Encloses a draft. The business with Beall still lingers. There is a discrepancy on how many acres on which Mackay or Mrs. Tallmadge is being taxed. The sale with C. Giddings is not finished.
Has negotiated a sale of land to William Gould and would like Mrs. Flewwelling's approval.
Encloses a draft. Would like to be informed about Mrs. Flewwelling's decision regarding a land sale. Has not heard from the rail road company agent.
Has received the Mrs. Flewwelling's deed and will deliver it. Encloses a draft.
Encloses a draft. His health is not very good.
Encloses a draft. Reports on Barnum, French and Sexton, and Warren contracts.
Encloses a draft. Reports on Warren contract.
Provides a statement of payments made by Thomas Warren and John Warren and encloses a survey of their property.

did.unittitle: Survey of property of Warren, T. L. and Warren, J. B.

scopecontent.p: The survey referred to in Millard to Mackay, Jun 8, 1852 (previous item).

Michael Norton, John Campbell, and Neil Campbell wish to purchase land of Mrs. Flewwelling and Millard requests instructions. Wishes also advice on the taxes charged to Mackay and Mr. Tallmadge on land in excess of 100 acres. Millard's health is better.

Acknowledges receipt of Barnum and Drier deeds. He has had the land surveyed Mr. Norton proposes to buy and thinks it will be a good bargain for Mrs. Flewwelling. Would like instructions. Relates what he has learned about the amount of land owned on by Mrs. Tallmadge and Mrs. Flewwelling and taxes on it. He has held back funds at the request of Henry Canfield.
Encloses a draft and reports that Mr. Norton would like to purchase entire lot if Mrs. Flewwelling approves.

did.unittitle: Canfield, Henry to Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: Reports that a man named Finney is interested in purchasing 96 acres in Rockport and suggests she approve the sale unless she has made no previous arrangements.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Flewwelling, Julia Canfield and Phinney, Benjamin

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.
Provides a detailed accounting of taxes paid for the years 1849-1852 on lands owned by Julia Canfield Flewwelling, William Mackay, Elizabeth Canfield Tallmadge, and Caroline Canfield Mackay.
Acknowledges receipt of Benjamin Phinney's deed. Offers explanation for discrepancies in his account. Provides additional detailed information regarding Mrs. Flewwelling's and Mrs. Tallmadge's taxes.
Encloses a draft and Mr. Phinney's contract.
Reports on a draft sent and encloses one.
Matters related to Mrs. Flewwelling's property insurance.
Matters related to Mrs. Flewwelling's property insurance.
Matters relating to Mrs. Flewwelling's property insurance.
Millard responds to Mackay's request for receipts for taxes paid. Reverse has Mackay's calculations.

did.unittitle: Agreement between Flewwelling, Julia Canfield and Norton, Michael

scopecontent.p: For the purchase of property in Rockport, Ohio.
Encloses a draft. Happy to hear of Mackay's safe return from Cincinnati. Millard's health is improving.
Discusses Phinney mortgage and Barnum's payment in full, encloses a draft for Miss J. F. Ruggles
Encloses his draft per agreement executed by Mackay and Mrs. Flewwelling.

did.unittitle: Statement of an account prepared by Canfield, William

scopecontent.p: Encloses a draft and deeds. His health has been poor.

did.unittitle: Power of attorney, Munson, Laura to Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: Responds in detail to Mackay's inquiry regarding a tax.
Discusses the payment of taxes.
Encloses a draft per the agreement executed by Mackay and Mrs. Flewwelling. Discusses the interests of the heirs of P. Cheney in lot 79, which he had purchased from Mrs. Flewwelling.
Writes regarding the discharge of the claim involving him and Mr. Hayes. Also remarks on links wanting from the chain of title but is hope there will be no trouble because of it.
Responds to Hilliard's letter regarding the discharge of the Hilliard and Hayes claim.
He does not have records that indicate there is a balance due as indicated by Mackay, but will consult with Mr. Hayes about the matter.

did.unittitle: Receipt, Mackay, William from Hilliard, Richard

scopecontent.p: Last installment due on his 1844 agreement.

Reports that his long-time bank, the Canal Bank of Cleveland, has failed and he had recently made deposits there. The cashier believes the bank will prove solvent, but that it will take time to close.
Statement of Millard's account as of the time of his death calculated by U. S. Bristol.

did.unittitle: Murray, Lucy to Flewwelling, Julia Canfield

scopecontent.p: She writes regarding her payment due April 1 and the failure of the Canal Bank.
Encloses a draft and discusses her payment.
Encloses a draft per the agreement executed by Mackay and Mrs. Flewwelling. Discusses the interest of the heirs of P. Cheney in lot 79.
Discusses payment of his mortgage. Mackay's response, dated May 15, 1855 is on the reverse. He suggests that French review the terms of the contract.

French copies portions of the contract into his letter and insists he and Saxton have done nothing that is not within the terms of the contract. Mackay's response, dated May 22, 1855, is on the reverse. He writes that he made a mistake.
He and Saxton are ready to make a payment on the land they bought of Mrs. Flewwelling.
Mackay appears to have misunderstood what French proposed in a previous letter. He restates what he intended and proposes to make payments on the purchased land.
Discusses French's letter in which he says he will pay up in full for his land and wishes to receive a deed.
Seeks advice on what amount he should pay for the interest of the heirs of P. Cheney in lot 79.
He encloses a quit claim deed from Julia Canfield Flewwelling to Clark and Hilliard and discusses the P. Cheney claim.
Encloses a draft and provides an accounting of funds received and expenses.
McKanna and Bronson should be notified that they must pay something.
Discusses the matter of P. Cheney's heirs and lot 79.
Reports that the Canal Bank will pay a dividend to depositors December next if there is any to pay.

He reports on inspecting Mrs. Flewwelling's Rockport papers after Henry Canfield's funeral. Even after looking at the papers, he is wholly ignorant on the conditions of the contracts and the lands. He discusses taxes recently paid on lands owned by Mrs. Flewwelling, Mackay, and Mr. and Mrs. Tallmadge. He will need lists of contracts, deeds, and owners, and a power of attorney from Mrs. Flewwelling to resolve matters.

did.unittitle: Demarest, D. D. to Mackay, William

scopecontent.p: Regarding Mrs. Flewwelling's property insurance.

did.unittitle: Demarest, D. D. to Mackay, William

scopecontent.p: Regarding Mrs. Flewwelling's property insurance.

He is in Cleveland to conclude the sale of Mrs. Tallmadge's lands. He encloses a draft. Reports on his busy schedule. Bronson's crops failed last year and he offers to sell his land. Canfield has been unable to find any purchasers for the rest of the lands. The severe cold weather has damaged crops and will amount to millions of dollars and cause great pecuniary distress for two or three years. He is unable to get anything for Mrs. Flewwelling at present. Mentions dividend on C. Ticknor's estate and the Cisco farm.

Acknowledges receipt of the draft and says he sent two deeds a week ago. He regrets to hear such discouraging accounts of the destruction caused by the frost and trusts the results will not be so bad. He hopes that Mr. Bronson may succeed in making some arrangement to pay on his account. Glad to be able to sell Cisco farm.

did.unittitle: Bristol, U. S. to Mackay, William

scopecontent.p: Discusses dividend paid by Canal Bank, Mrs. Flewwelling's account, taxes, and closing the account with the estate of Royal Millard.

did.unittitle: Mackay, William to Bristol, U. S.

scopecontent.p: He has concluded to settle with the estate of Royal Millard as Bristol proposes. Will be in Concord, Mass., next week and the settle in New York for the winter.

did.unittitle: Bristol, U. S. to Mackay, William

scopecontent.p: Discusses dividend paid by Canal Bank, Mrs. Flewwelling's account, taxes, and closing the account with the estate of Royal Millard. Includes a statement of account taken from Millard's account book.

did.unittitle: Mackay, William to Bristol, U. S.

scopecontent.p: His reply to Bristol's letter of Dec 28, 1859, regarding the Canal Bank and Mrs. Flewwelling's account.

did.unittitle: Bristol, U. S. to McKay, William

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges Mackay's letter of Jan 14, 1860, and provides a receipt for payment for money advanced by Royal Millard on behalf of Mrs. Flewwelling. Mackay's reply, dated, Feb 5, 1860, acknowledging Bristol's receipt and returning the agreement, is on the reverse.

6 items relating to the sale of the Harding farm in Iowa by Abel Harding, a relative of Samuel Flewwelling, of Racine, Wisc., which discuss family information, a description of the property, and conditions of the sale. Correspondents are G. W. Gilbert, Eliza Harding, Abel Harding.

did.unittitle: Statement of Munson house in New Rochelle to James W. Todd
Trust established for Munson, Maria Louisa by Flewwelling, Julia Canfield from the proceeds of the payment of a mortgage on a house owned by Munson, Laura
Receipts, Munson, Laura Louisa and Munson, Fred A.

scopecontent.p: 2 items. Receipts from Laura Louisa Munson and Fred A. Munson related to funds distrubuted from the estate of Julia Canfield Flewwelling and the payment of a mortgage on property owned by Laura Munson.

did.unittitle: List of a lease and deeds

scopecontent.p: Lists a lease and deeds involving Samuel Flewwelling, Julia Canfield Flewwelling, Henry Canfield, Frederick Tallmadge, Elizabeth Canfield Tallmadge, William Lane, and Pamela Hubbell Lane.
List of acreage in various sections that ought to be quit claimed by the State of Connecticut to Judson Canfield.

did.unittitle: Sketch of lots on Boardman Road and Canfield Street
Wrapper, memo. of contracts for land [accounts] made by S. F. [Samuel Flewwelling]

scopecontent.p: In William Mackay's hand.
